text: Does anyone know stories about memoization? I want to give a presentation about a memoization system and it will be nice to open with a real world story.

elements.text: Does anyone know stories about memoization? I want to give a presentation about a memoization system and it will be nice to open with a real world story.

text:
Parsing date times.
For loading CSVs.
Parsing a datetime is relatively fast, but not as fast as hashing a datetime length string.
And since in a spatial-temporal/panel dataset (one indexed by time and location) each time stamp is repreated for each location (so thousands of times for us) this gives big gains.

Especially because parsing real world data is messy. Parsing a date time actually means calling `tryparse` up to 5 or 6 times to try and find out what format it actually is in.

Adding a cache around the parse have a 7x speedup on total data loading time. Over 1 hour down to under 10 minutes.

Also cut down on memory use since it wasn't allocating fresh memory for each.

text:
This is a real story.
Parsing was slow.
We added memoization to parsing and now it is fast.
Everyone lived happily ever after

elements.text:
This is a real story.
Parsing was slow.
We added memoization to parsing and now it is fast.
Everyone lived happily ever after

text:
My memoization story is more about big chunks not small chunks. So in data pipelines with new code(ie where things can go wrong), it's really helpful to memoize intermediate results.

Big dataset A -> transform1 -> transform2 -> transform3(fails) -> transform4

I've saved days of my life doing this. Think I wrote a macro to help with it at some point...

files.preview:
using TimeZones, Dates
using Memento  # Logging library

timestamp_parser(x::Integer) = TimeZones.unix2zdt(x)
timestamp_parser(str::Missing) = missing
files.preview_highlight:
using TimeZones, Dates
using Memento  # Logging library
​
timestamp_parser(x::Integer) = TimeZones.unix2zdt(x)
timestamp_parser(str::Missing) = missing

text:
Memoization is just

```foo(x) = # do the hard thing

const _FOO_CACHE=Dict{K, V}()  # set K and V to input and output types
cached_foo(x) = get!(()->foo(x), _FOO_CACHE, x)```

elements.text: Memoization is just

foo(x) = # do the hard thing

const _FOO_CACHE=Dict{K, V}()  # set K and V to input and output types
cached_foo(x) = get!(()->foo(x), _FOO_CACHE, x)

text: I do understand the concept, but it seems to be a tool I've underestimated significantly. At least memoizing small calculations in such a way never occured to me (let's just blame this on Python being my first real programming language after Matlab :joy:).

elements.text: I do understand the concept, but it seems to be a tool I've underestimated significantly. At least memoizing small calculations in such a way never occured to me (let's just blame this on Python being my first real programming language after Matlab

text: I like to memoize/cache big stuff to disk incase I OOM, or something else(like try to plot data with 5000000, rows)

elements.text: I like to memoize/cache big stuff to disk incase I OOM, or something else(like try to plot data with 5000000, rows)

text: think the idea isn't to memoize small calculations, it's that you memoize the result of small calculations done many many times. There's a good example of this with the fibonacci sequence that is often used as an interview question for junior developers

elements.text: think the idea isn't to memoize small calculations, it's that you memoize the result of small calculations done many many times. There's a good example of this with the fibonacci sequence that is often used as an interview question for junior developers

text:
Ok, giving more background.
the loading of this data was a key constraining factor on testing and on  experiments.
This made t 7x faster, from 1hour -> 10 minutes for the large, and from 2 minutes->2 seconds for the small.

We don’t load data from CSVs for the production systems, we have a database for that.
But we don’t want to snow our database under a million random queries from hyperopt running.
and we don’t want to complicate our CI by making it have to connect to a database for test data.
and we want a quick safe playground of data for early research work, that is distinct from the database being used to evaluate it.
All those things require fast CSV parsing.

If you have to way 1 hour for data to load before you can start an experiment, that really cramps your style when it comes to innovating.
If you are spending an hour loading data from files on the big expensive 96 core machines we rent for hyperopt that is a waste of money.
If you have to way 2 minutes for data to load to test, then you are not going to test things properly and your CI will be a pain.

So the flashy story is:
1 RSE uses cool trick to make things much faster, researchers and developers love him.

attachments.title: The Nonlinear Effect of Code Speed on Productivity - Stochastic Lifestyle
attachments.text: I obsess over code performance, probably a little bit too much. But there's a big reason for wanting a code to run in less than an hour instead of slightly more than two hours. The reason is because a code's speed interacts with how we go about our day, and this speed can have a nonlinear effect on our productivity. Here's a concrete example. When I was a PhD student, I had a project which was solving ensembles of stochastic partial differential equations which were a model of the zebrafish hindbrain. Each run of this ensemble took about two hours and ten minutes to perform. For a good chunk of time, I needed to keep running these ensembles in order to manually check the output to tweak the model until it started to look realistic. Tweaking the model took only a ... READ MORE
